meta.title: "Grab and Go" meal program working in response to coronavirus closures

meta.name: description
meta.content: Kitsap and North Mason schools deliver thousands of meals daily to kids while schools are closed to curtail the spread of coronavirus

Buy Photo
Phillip Hardy Jr., 6, happily accepts a carton of milk from Jessi Carson, kitchen lead at West Hills STEM Academy, on Friday. School districts have been using buses to deliver meals daily to school sites and bus stops along selected routes. (Photo: MEEGAN M. REID / KITSAP SUN)
BREMERTON — Danielle Hardy and her six kids, 2 to 19, piled out of their minivan Friday at West Hills STEM Academy to pick up breakfast and lunch packaged in bags for the children.
With husband Phillip Hardy Sr. in the Navy, they're a single-income family, so having two out of three meals covered on weekdays helps both financially and logistically, Danielle said.
Families say there are other benefits to the "grab-and-go" meal program that started March 17 after Gov. Jay Inslee ordered schools across the state to close in response to the spread of coronavirus.
"Going to the school every day to pick up breakfast and lunch gives some sense of normalcy for my kids," Danielle said.
Buy Photo
West Hills STEM Academy counselor Kasia Roque loads weekend meals packaged by the Bremerton Backpack Brigade into her car for distribution at the school on Friday, March 27, 2020. (Photo: MEEGAN M. REID / KITSAP SUN)
The demand for grab-and-go meals in Bremerton has doubled in less than two weeks. A total of 1,207 meals were served the first day, with 2,436 served Monday.
"We are expecting the numbers are going to keep going up each week," said district spokeswoman Karen Bevers.
Bremerton schools enroll around 5,000 students, 66% of whom are low-income. As of Wednesday, the district had served 13,653 meals.
Kitsap and North Mason school districts combined served more than 11,000 meals per day during the week starting March 23.
Meals continue under Inslee's order
Districts have been using buses to deliver meals daily to school sites, and in the case of Bremerton and North Mason, to bus stops along selected routes.
Delivery of school meals is considered a critical public service and will continue under Inslee's order issued March 23 for all non-essential workers to stay home. With the order, Bremerton on Monday will adjust its meal delivery schedule, staffing and routes.
Meals will be delivered two days a week instead of daily. Students will still get five breakfasts and five lunches per week as they will get two days of meals on Monday, and three days of meals on Wednesday.
Buy Photo
Teacher Katrina Jones laughs with coworkers as she loads meals onto a bus at West Hills STEM Academy on Friday. (Photo: MEEGAN M. REID / KITSAP SUN)
Half of the foodservice staff will serve one day, half the other. Other staff members, including teachers, have been asked to staff delivery buses or fill in other gaps. Participation is not mandatory, Bevers said.
"Shifts are filling up fast," she said. "They love to see their students.
Some delivery routes have been consolidated to streamline staffing, Bevers said, but a few more stops have been added on each route. School meal sites now are limited to Bremerton High School, Armin Jahr Elementary and West Hills STEM Academy.
'Building an airplane as we fly'
The state's mandate that districts continue feeding children throughout the pandemic is testing the flexibility and ingenuity of school administrators and workers. The task involves not only food service workers but bus drivers, mechanics and custodians, paraeducators and other support staff.
IT techs in Bremerton and North Mason have been working on getting internet access to families who lack laptops or Wi-fi so they can continue learning activities. Bremerton has been delivering Chromebooks to some families on the meal buses.
Buy Photo
Jessi Carson, kitchen lead at West Hills STEM Academy, loads a bus with meals ready for delivery on Friday. (Photo: MEEGAN M. REID / KITSAP SUN)
Justin Feltus, president of the Bremerton schools' chapter of SEIU Local 925 representing school support staff, said the district and union have been working cooperatively in uncharted territory.
"We're building an airplane as we fly it," said. "Are there cracks in the system? I'm sure there are but right now, they're being held together by people working really hard. I'm damn proud of them."
Concerns for worker safety
Like other essential service employees, school staff face the increased possibility of exposure to coronavirus. Concerns for worker safety have been addressed to the best of everyone's ability given the circumstances, Feltus said. Supplies needed to deliver the meals, including hygiene items, are adequate but not abundant.
"We are using existing supplies and substituting alternatives for sanitation that are approved by the Kitsap Public Health District," Bevers said.
Workers 60 and older and those with underlying health issues are now allowed to stay home from work. Sixteen workers have taken this option since it was announced March 16, Bevers said.
"This is a scary time for everybody," Feltus said. "I think everybody's doing as much as they can. Frankly, I think school districts weren't designed to be the National Guard, and frankly, that's what we're being used as right now. We're being asked to feed people, and our folks in CNS (child nutrition services) and bus services feel a lot of pride in that. But schools weren't designed to be disaster relief agencies so we're doing the best with what we've got."
Hard to practice for a pandemic
Troy Grubb, SEIU 925 representative for South Kitsap School District, like Feltus is proud of his members and satisfied with how the district is responding.
"I've heard concerns. We've all had concerns. We're all in the dark, not knowing what this is," Grubb said. "But I haven't heard a lot of complaints. ... Considering the fact we don't practice epidemics every year like we do fire alarms, considering the fact we don't have experience in that area, the district and our group, the unions, I think we're working very well together. South Kitsap has been very compassionate toward the human side of things."
South Kitsap serves meals daily at 13 of its school sites and distributes 1,400 breakfasts and 1,400 lunches each day, according to spokeswoman Amy Miller.
"We have worked closely with the Kitsap Public Health District and have really appreciated the support of the entire South Kitsap team," Miller said. "The (food and nutrition services) team has been creative in meal planning and has not run into shortages of meal items yet. Absenteeism hasn't been an issue and we are doing our best to accommodate staff concerns."
'It's the right thing to do'
Bremerton school bus driver Vanessa Lotz worries about exposing her children, ages 7 and 17, to the virus, but she has no qualms about working during the outbreak. Lotz said she did not feel pressure from the district to continue working.
"It is difficult, but it's something I'm actually excited to do to help out where I can," Lotz said. "I'm just concerned if I bring it home to my kids, but I feel I have to do it. It's just the right thing to do."
Buy Photo
Jamari Hardy, 15, walks little brother William, 2, down the sidewalk after the family picked up meals at West Hills STEM Academy on Friday. (Photo: MEEGAN M. REID / KITSAP SUN)
Back at West Hills, preschool teacher Katrina Jones ran out to the curb to deliver meals to the family of one of her students. James Silvers, 5, restrained in a car seat waved his arms and beamed when he saw her.
"Every time we come to school, he's so upset he can't be with her," said mom Elizabeth Kennedy.
Jones, who is filling in on meal delivery, said that like Lotz, she feels called to keep working amid the coronavirus outbreak.
"I feel it's important to make sure our families not only get fed, but that they know we're here for them, and there's that sense of community." Jones said. "Everyone's working really hard to get us through these crazy times."
Chris Henry reports on education and community news for the Kitsap Sun. Reach her at (360) 792-9219 or christina.henry@kitsapsun.com. Support coverage of local news by signing up today for a digital subscription.
